article.title: New constraints and discovery potential of sub-GeV dark matter with xenon detectors

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main obstacle faced by direct detection experiments searching for sub-GeV dark matter?
choices: The energy deposited in a detector by sub-GeV DM is small.
The interaction cross-section of sub-GeV DM is extremely low.
Sub-GeV DM interacts too frequently with the detector material, leading to saturation.
The technology to detect sub-GeV DM does not yet exist.

multiple_choice_question.text: What new signal channel was proposed in Ref. [33] to probe sub-GeV DM using existing xenon detectors?
choices: Detection of acoustic signals produced by DM interactions.
Measurement of temperature variations within the xenon target.
Search for the irreducible photon emission from a polarised xenon atom.
Analysis of secondary particles produced in DM-nucleus collisions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the role of the factor Fmed(ER) in the DM-nucleus cross-section parameterization?
choices: Accounts for the energy loss due to photon emission.
Represents the nuclear form factor.
Depends on the mass of the particle mediating the interaction.
Normalizes the cross-section to a reference momentum transfer value.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why do the authors assume that the nuclear recoil signal from the DM interaction is not observable in dual-phase xenon detectors?
choices: The recoil energy is below the detection threshold.
The nuclear recoil signal is indistinguishable from background.
Theoretical arguments suggest that no observable signal is produced.
The article doesn't mention any assumption about the observability of the nuclear recoil signal.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the improved sensitivity of the LUX WS2014-16 analysis compared to WS2013?
choices: Increased exposure time.
Higher light collection efficiency.
Lower background levels.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the advantage of the profile likelihood ratio (PLR) method over the cut-and-count (CC) approach?
choices: The PLR method is computationally less demanding.
The PLR method takes into account the S1 and S2 information of each event, increasing sensitivity.
The PLR method does not require a background model.
The PLR method is less sensitive to systematic uncertainties.

multiple_choice_question.text: Compared to existing limits from XENON100 and CRESST-II, how do the LUX constraints on the DM-nucleon cross-section compare?
choices: LUX constraints are significantly weaker.
LUX constraints are comparable.
LUX constraints are significantly stronger.
LUX constraints are only relevant for a different DM mass range.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary advantage of dual-phase xenon detectors like LUX and LZ in the context of sub-GeV DM searches?
choices: Large target mass.
Low energy threshold.
Ability to discriminate between signal and background events.
Sensitivity to a wide range of DM masses.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the dominant background source for both NR and ER events within the fiducial volume of LZ?
choices: Cosmogenic muons
Radiogenic contamination
Solar neutrinos
Reactor neutrinos
